title: John Roseboro
text:
John Junior Roseboro (May 13, 1933 – August 16, 2002) was an <a href="Americans">American</a> professional <a href="baseball">baseball</a> player and <a href="Coach%20%28baseball%29">coach</a>. He played as a <a href="catcher">catcher</a> in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> from 1957 until 1970, most prominently as a member of the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers">Los Angeles Dodgers</a>. A four-time <a href="MLB%20All-Star%20Game">All-Star</a> player, Roseboro is considered one of the best defensive catchers of the 1960s, winning two <a href="Rawlings%20Gold%20Glove%20Award">Gold Glove Awards</a>. He was the Dodgers' starting catcher in four <a href="World%20Series">World Series</a> with the Dodgers winning three of those. Roseboro was known for his role in one of the most violent incidents in baseball history when <a href="Juan%20Marichal">Juan Marichal</a> struck him in the head with a <a href="Baseball%20bat">bat</a> during a game in 1965.
Baseball career.
Early life in professional baseball.
Roseboro was born in <a href="Ashland%2C%20Ohio">Ashland, Ohio</a>, and enrolled at <a href="Central%20State%20University">Central State University</a>. He was signed by the Brooklyn Dodgers as an amateur free agent before the <a href="1952%20Brooklyn%20Dodgers%20season">1952</a> season and, began his <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> career with the <a href="Sheboygan%20Indians">Sheboygan Indians</a> of the <a href="Wisconsin%20State%20League">Wisconsin State League</a>. He posted a .365 <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a> with Sheboygan in 1952 to finish second in the league batting championship. Roseboro missed the 1954 season due to military service but, after five years in the <a href="Minor%20league%20baseball">minor leagues</a>, he was promoted to the major leagues in June 1957 at the age of 24.
Campanella's heir apparent.
During his first season, Roseboro served as backup catcher for the Dodgers' perennial All-Star catcher <a href="Roy%20Campanella">Roy Campanella</a> and was being groomed to be Campanella's replacement. However, he was promoted to the starting catcher's position ahead of schedule when Campanella had a tragic car accident in January 1958 that ended his career. In his first full season, with the team having moved to Los Angeles, Roseboro hit for a .271 batting average along with 14 <a href="home%20run">home run</a>s and 43 <a href="runs%20batted%20in">runs batted in</a>. He was also named as a reserve player for the <a href="National%20League">National League</a> in the <a href="1958%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20All-Star%20Game">1958 All-Star game</a>. In <a href="1959%20Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers%20season">1959</a>, Roseboro led the league's catchers in <a href="putout">putout</a>s and in baserunners <a href="caught%20stealing">caught stealing</a>, helping the Dodgers win the <a href="List%20of%20National%20League%20pennant%20winners">National League Pennant</a>. The Dodgers went on to win the <a href="1959%20World%20Series">1959 World Series</a>, defeating the <a href="1959%20Chicago%20White%20Sox%20season">Chicago White Sox</a> in six games.
After having a below par season in <a href="1960%20Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers%20season">1960</a>, Roseboro rebounded in <a href="1961%20Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers%20season">1961</a> posting career highs with 18 home runs and 59 runs batted in. He also led the National League catchers in putouts and <a href="double%20play">double play</a>s and finished second in <a href="fielding%20percentage">fielding percentage</a> and in <a href="Assist%20%28baseball%29">assists</a> to earn his first Gold Glove Award when the Dodgers finished the season in second place behind the <a href="1961%20Cincinnati%20Reds%20season">Cincinnati Reds</a>. He also earned his second All-Star team berth as a reserve player in the <a href="1961%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20All-Star%20Game%20%28second%20game%29">1961 All-Star game</a>. He won his third All-Star berth as a reserve in the <a href="1962%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20All-Star%20Game%20%28first%20game%29">1962 All-Star game</a>. The Dodgers battled the <a href="1962%20San%20Francisco%20Giants%20season">San Francisco Giants</a> in a tight pennant race during the <a href="1962%20Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers%20season">1962</a> season with the two teams ending the season tied for first place and met in the <a href="1962%20National%20League%20tie-breaker%20series">1962 National League tie-breaker series</a>. The Giants won the three-game series to clinch the National League championship.
Roseboro helped guide the Dodgers' pitching staff to a league leading 2.85 <a href="earned%20run%20average">earned run average</a> in <a href="1963%20Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers%20season">1963</a> as the Dodgers clinched the National League Pennant by 6 games over the <a href="1963%20St.%20Louis%20Cardinals%20season">St. Louis Cardinals</a>. Roseboro made his presence felt in the <a href="1963%20World%20Series">1963 World Series</a> against the <a href="1963%20New%20York%20Yankees%20season">New York Yankees</a> when he hit a three-run home run off <a href="Whitey%20Ford">Whitey Ford</a> to win the first game of the series. The Dodgers went on to win the series by defeating the Yankees in four straight games. The Dodgers dropped to seventh place in the <a href="1964%20Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers%20season">1964</a> season, however Roseboro hit for a career high .287 batting average and led the league's catchers with a 60.4% caught stealing percentage, the ninth highest season percentage in major league history.
Marichal incident.
Roseboro was involved in a major altercation with <a href="Juan%20Marichal">Juan Marichal</a> during a game between the Dodgers and <a href="San%20Francisco%20Giants">San Francisco Giants</a> at <a href="Candlestick%20Park">Candlestick Park</a> on August 22, 1965. The Giants and the Dodgers had nurtured a heated <a href="Dodgers%E2%80%93Giants%20rivalry">rivalry</a> with each other dating back to their days together in the New York City market. As the 1965 season neared its climax, the Dodgers were involved in a tight pennant race, entering the game leading the <a href="1965%20Milwaukee%20Braves%20season">Milwaukee Braves</a> by half a game and the Giants by one and a half games. The incident occurred in the aftermath of the <a href="Watts%20riots">Watts riots</a> near Roseboro's Los Angeles home and while the <a href="Dominican%20Civil%20War">Dominican Civil War</a> raged in Marichal's home country, so emotions were raw.
<a href="Maury%20Wills">Maury Wills</a> led off the game with a <a href="Bunt%20%28baseball%29">bunt</a> single off Marichal, and eventually scored a <a href="Run%20%28baseball%29">run</a> when <a href="Ron%20Fairly">Ron Fairly</a> hit a <a href="Double%20%28baseball%29">double</a>. Marichal, a fierce competitor, viewed the bunt as a cheap way to get on base and took umbrage with Wills. When Wills came up to bat in the second <a href="Inning%20%28baseball%29">inning</a>, Marichal threw a pitch directly at Wills, sending him sprawling to the ground. <a href="Willie%20Mays">Willie Mays</a> then led off the bottom of the second inning for the Giants and Dodgers' pitcher <a href="Sandy%20Koufax">Sandy Koufax</a> threw a pitch over Mays' head as a token form of retaliation. In the top of the third inning with two <a href="Out%20%28baseball%29">outs</a>, Marichal threw a <a href="fastball">fastball</a> that came close to hitting Fairly, prompting him to dive to the ground. Marichal's act angered the Dodgers sitting in the <a href="Dugout%20%28baseball%29">dugout</a> and home plate umpire <a href="Shag%20Crawford">Shag Crawford</a> then warned both teams that any further retaliations would not be tolerated.
Marichal came to bat in the third inning expecting Koufax to take further retaliation against him but instead, he was startled when Roseboro's return throw to Koufax after the second pitch either brushed his ear or came close enough for him to feel the breeze off the ball. When Marichal confronted Roseboro about the proximity of his throw, Roseboro came out of his crouch with his fists clenched. Marichal afterwards stated that he thought Roseboro was about to attack him and raised his bat, striking Roseboro at least twice over the head with it, opening a two-inch gash that sent blood flowing down the catcher's face and required 14 stitches. Koufax raced in from the mound to attempt to separate them and was joined by the umpires, players and coaches from both teams.
A 14-minute brawl ensued on the field before Koufax, Giants captain Willie Mays and other peacemakers restored order. Marichal was ejected from the game and afterwards, National League president <a href="Warren%20Giles">Warren Giles</a> suspended him for eight games (two starts), fined him a then-NL record US$1,750 (), and also forbade him from traveling to <a href="Dodger%20Stadium">Dodger Stadium</a> for the final, crucial two-game series of the season. Roseboro filed a $110,000 damage suit against Marichal one week after the incident, but eventually settled out of court for $7,500.
Years later, Roseboro stated that he was retaliating for Marichal's having thrown at Wills. He explained that Koufax would not throw at batters for fear of hurting them due to the velocity of his pitches. He further stated that his throwing close to Marichal's ear was, "standard operating procedure", as a form of retribution. Marichal didn't face the Dodgers again until <a href="spring%20training">spring training</a> on April 3, 1966. In his first at bat against Marichal after the incident, Roseboro hit a three-run home run. San Francisco General Manager <a href="Chub%20Feeney">Chub Feeney</a> approached Dodgers General Manager <a href="Buzzy%20Bavasi">Buzzy Bavasi</a> to attempt to arrange a handshake between Marichal and Roseboro, but Roseboro declined the offer.
Dodger fans remained angry with Marichal for several years after the altercation, and reacted unfavorably when he was signed by the Dodgers in <a href="1975%20Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers%20season">1975</a>. By then, however, Roseboro had forgiven Marichal, and personally appealed to fans to do the same.
Later career.
The Dodgers went on to win the <a href="1965%20Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers%20season">1965</a> National League Pennant by two games over the Giants. Even though the Giants won the two games against the Dodgers during which Marichal had been suspended, the outcome of the season may have been different without the Giants' pitcher's suspension, as he finished the season with a 22-13 <a href="Win%E2%80%93loss%20record%20%28pitching%29">win-loss</a> record. Roseboro once again guided the Dodgers' pitching staff to a league-leading 2.81 earned run average. He caught for two twenty-game winners in 1965 with Koufax winning 26 games, while <a href="Don%20Drysdale">Don Drysdale</a> won 23 games. In his book, "<a href="The%20Bill%20James%20Historical%20Baseball%20Abstract">The Bill James Historical Baseball Abstract</a>", baseball historian <a href="Bill%20James">Bill James</a> said the decision to give <a href="Joe%20Torre">Joe Torre</a> a 1965 National League Gold Glove Award was absurd, stating that he was given the award because of his offensive statistics and that either Roseboro or <a href="Tom%20Haller">Tom Haller</a> was more deserving of the award. In the <a href="1965%20World%20Series">1965 World Series</a> against the <a href="1965%20Minnesota%20Twins%20season">Minnesota Twins</a>, Roseboro contributed a two-run <a href="Single%20%28baseball%29">single</a> to win Game 3 of the series as, the Dodgers went on to win the world championship in seven games.
The Dodgers' pitching staff continued to lead the league in earned-run averages in <a href="1966%20Los%20Angeles%20Dodgers%20season">1966</a> as they battled with the <a href="1966%20San%20Francisco%20Giants%20season">San Francisco Giants</a> and the <a href="1966%20Pittsburgh%20Pirates%20season">Pittsburgh Pirates</a> in a tight pennant race. The Dodgers eventually prevailed to win the National League Pennant for a second consecutive year. Roseboro led the league with a career-high 903 putouts and finished second to Joe Torre in fielding percentage to win his second Gold Glove Award. The Dodgers would eventually lose the <a href="1966%20World%20Series">1966 World Series</a>, getting swept in four games by the <a href="1966%20Baltimore%20Orioles%20season">Baltimore Orioles</a>.
After the Dodgers fell to 8th place, Roseboro, <a href="Ron%20Perranoski">Ron Perranoski</a> and <a href="Bob%20Miller%20%28baseball%2C%20born%201939%29">Bob Miller</a> were acquired by the <a href="Minnesota%20Twins">Minnesota Twins</a>, which needed a veteran catcher and left-handed reliever, in exchange for <a href="Mudcat%20Grant">Mudcat Grant</a> and <a href="Zoilo%20Versalles">Zoilo Versalles</a> on November 28, 1967. While with the Twins, he would be named to his fourth and final All-Star team when he was named as a reserve for the <a href="American%20League">American League</a> team in the <a href="1969%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20All-Star%20Game">1969 All-Star game</a>. After the season, Roseboro was released by the Twins. He signed as a <a href="free%20agent">free agent</a> with the <a href="Washington%20Senators%20%281961%E2%80%9371%29">Washington Senators</a> on December 31, 1969 but appeared in only 46 games for the last place Senators. He played in his final major league game on August 11, <a href="1970%20Washington%20Senators%20season">1970</a> at the age of 37.
Career statistics.
In a fourteen-year major league career, Roseboro played in 1,585 <a href="Games%20played">games</a>, accumulating 1,206 <a href="Hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a> in 4,847 <a href="at%20bats">at bats</a> for a .249 career batting average along with 104 home runs, 548 runs batted in and an <a href="on-base%20percentage">on-base percentage</a> of .326. He had a .989 career fielding percentage as a catcher. Roseboro caught 112 <a href="shutouts%20in%20baseball">shutouts</a> during his career, ranking him 19th all-time among major league catchers. He was the catcher for two of Sandy Koufax's four <a href="no-hitter">no-hitter</a>s and caught more than 100 games in 11 of his 14 major league seasons. Baseball historian Bill James ranked Roseboro 27th all-time among major league catchers.
Later life.
After completing his playing career with Washington, Roseboro coached for the Senators (1971) and <a href="California%20Angels">California Angels</a> (1972–74). Later, he served as a <a href="Minor%20league%20baseball">minor league</a> batting instructor (1977) and catching instructor (1987) for the Dodgers. Roseboro and his wife, Barbara Fouch Roseboro, also owned a <a href="Beverly%20Hills">Beverly Hills</a> <a href="public%20relations">public relations</a> firm.
Roseboro appeared as a <a href="Undercover%20operation%23Plainclothes%20law%20enforcement">plainclothes</a> officer in the 1966 "<a href="Dragnet%20%28series%29%231966%20television%20series">Dragnet</a>" TV movie. He also appeared as himself in the 1962 film "<a href="Experiment%20in%20Terror">Experiment in Terror</a>" along with <a href="Don%20Drysdale">Don Drysdale</a> and <a href="Wally%20Moon">Wally Moon</a>, and as himself in the 1963 "<a href="Mister%20Ed">Mister Ed</a>" episode "Leo Durocher Meets Mister Ed."
<a href="Chevrolet">Chevrolet</a> was one of the sponsors of the Dodgers' radio coverage in the mid-1960s. The song "See the USA in Your Chevrolet", made famous by <a href="Dinah%20Shore">Dinah Shore</a> in the '50s, was sung in Chevrolet commercials by Roseboro and other Dodger players. Dodger announcer <a href="Jerry%20Doggett">Jerry Doggett</a> once joked that Roseboro was a singer "whose singing career was destined to go absolutely nowhere."
After several years of bitterness over their famous altercation, Roseboro and Marichal became friends in the 1980s. Roseboro personally appealed to the <a href="Baseball%20Writers%27%20Association%20of%20America">Baseball Writers' Association of America</a> not to hold the incident against Marichal after he was passed over for election to the <a href="Baseball%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Hall of Fame</a> in his first two years of eligibility. Marichal was elected in <a href="Baseball%20Hall%20of%20Fame%20balloting%2C%201983">1983</a>, and thanked Roseboro during his induction speech. "There were no hard feelings on my part," Roseboro said, "and I thought if that was made public, people would believe that this was really over with. So I saw him at a Dodger old-timers' game, and we posed for pictures together, and I actually visited him in the Dominican. The next year, he was in the Hall of Fame. Hey, over the years, you learn to forget things."
Roseboro died of heart disease on August 16, 2002 in <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a> at age 69. Marichal served as an honorary pallbearer at his funeral. "Johnny's forgiving me was one of the best things that happened in my life," he said, at the service. "I wish I could have had John Roseboro as my catcher."
